segments.text: Hi Siddharth. Nice to meet you Rohit. How's it going? I'm doing well. Good good. So I'm just
doing a small research to understand how teenagers handle payments etc. So I'll
just be asking you few questions. That'd be fine right? Yep. And this conversation
will be recorded and will be used for research. Yep. Okay. So can you walk me through your
normal day and what all apps do you use throughout the day? Apps in general or just payment apps?
In general. Right. So let's start off with my day. So most days of the week I go to college
obviously. So my day starts out with preparing for university and then heading to university
and I'm spending anywhere from maybe 2 hours to 8 hours in a day. It varies quite a lot.
So once I come back, I have started a daily habit of going to the gym actually. And then
I study once in a while when the occasion comes. I work on my side projects as well
and I have a final year project going on as well which I work on my free time as well.
So the apps I use to be quite frank with you, I don't use my phone as much as I use my PC.
But on my phone, I would say I use YouTube the most but also not that much. Then the
second most category of apps I would say I like payment apps obviously because I use
my phone mostly for payments. That's it. Makes sense. So when was the last time you paid
for something? I think matter of fact it was yesterday. It was supposed to be today but
my bank balance ran out. So yeah, yesterday. Yeah. Can I know what did you pay for if that's
okay? Yeah, this is actually for snacks at my canteen. Okay. So what did you use to pay
this for this thing? The app? Yeah. So I use an app called super.money. Have you heard
Yeah, I do. That's the one by Flipkart, I believe. And they have like a cashback thing
on every payment. The main reason why I use it. So yeah, I use it for pretty much like
95 99% of my payments. Makes sense. So where did you hear about this in the beginning?
And why did you choose this as your app? So what I heard about it was actually from a
few of my friends. I had seen them using this app. And I had inquired about it looked pretty
interesting. And they told me about the cashback feature attack. That is primarily the main
reason that I use it up because of the cashback. Got it. So was this the first app you were
using? Or were you using something else before this? I was actually I initially got my bank
account sorted. I started using GP. Okay. Yeah. And then after GP for a while, I switched
to super.money. Can you just walk me through like, what made you shift from Google Pay
to like super money initially? What triggered you? So it wasn't regarding GP. Like the reason
I switched was not pertaining to any shortcomings of GP per se. It was mostly because, you know,
super money has a cashback feature. That is pretty much the only reason I switched back to it.
There's no other reason. Got it. So ever since you switched to the app, you are stuck to using
super.money? Yeah, I'm stuck to it. Yeah, pretty, pretty consistently. For most payments,
there are still a few payments, which, let's say like recurring payments and all. I don't,
I have a few payments on GP. For example, I still do my bank transfer on GP. So like in between my
banks. Yeah. Can you explain more like, why not on super.money? And why do you use GP for bank
transfers? The main philosophy is that I have two bank accounts. And one of them I use for my daily
transactions. And the other I use to hold like vast amount of other money. Right. So
as a sort of exercise in security, I guess you could say, I keep both banks on GP, but only one
bank on super.money. It's also a great way to, you know, kind of reduce my spending as well.
Because I don't want to be spending too much on a given day. Got it. It makes sense. So
um, have you, have you heard or used any other apps apart from these apps?
Um, I think I have, I can't remember the names of any. Okay, that's okay.
And going back to you, how you started using GP. So why did you first think like I should use GP
instead of any other app out there? What triggered you? Or what, what was the journey
of you installing that app? If I remember correctly, it was the first app I had on my phone.
And you know how, like I use an Android phone, right? So like, I would say Google has the most,
the best integration out of like any other service into the Android ecosystem. Like,
for example, if you use an iPhone, you're more inclined to use Apple.
Whatever they have, this is the most, the most well integrated service
there is for that particular platform. I would say that's the main reason why I started using it.
And I would still say, okay, like, if super money for whatever reason stops giving cash back, or
you know, it becomes more inconvenient to use, I would immediately switch back to GP.
So I think it's just far superior.
Okay. You feel it's superior because it's integrated into the Android ecosystem.
Not just that, there's a, there's a lot of small user experience, design things that make,
like, it just makes the quality of the app that much better than super, super money, right?
Interesting. If you may, can you just go deeper into why you think that way,
or any specific reasons or features, what makes you feel that way?
I would say the number one thing that stands out to me is on GP. Let's say, you can see the overall,
how do I put into words, like on GP, say, at the top of every month, you can see how much money
I've spent or how much money you have gained in total, right? So in a month, you spend 500,
but you gain 1000 on the GP app at the top, it's like plus 500 in green.
I think that's a very useful feature to know how much you're spending at a glance.
Okay.
So, if I may ask, like, what is like the biggest transaction you did using UPI?
Using UPI, I think around 70,000 rupees or 80,000 rupees.
Okay.
I believe there's a, there's a transfer limit of one lakh per day.
Transfer limit of one lakh per day, is it?
Yeah, it should be something around that.
Yeah.
That makes sense. So, on a monthly basis, if I can ask, like, how regularly do you use UPI?
On a monthly basis, I would say, so the past few months, the past year, actually, I've been
using UPI on a near regular, near daily basis. But I think ever since the new year, I've kind of
stopped my spending. So it's been at least once every three, four days, I would say.
Got it.
Yeah. It's not exactly like a linear thing. It's more, you know, sometimes there are stretches
that I pay pretty much every day. Sometimes I go a week without paying.
Got it. Makes sense.
And do you use these apps only for payments? Or do you use it for anything else?
Super money, pretty much only for payments and cashback.
What about Google Pay?
Google Pay, yeah, just for, you know, keeping checks and my balances and all that.
Makes sense. Okay.
Cool. Let's go into a different topic now. So, you know about credit cards, right? Like,
Yep, I do.
Yeah. Can you just tell me, what do you know about them?
So, I know that you need to have like an income, in most cases, at least,
to take a credit card or for banks to issue a credit card to you.
I also know that it's like taking many loans that you have to pay at the end of the month,
like we pay at the end of the month.
You know, if you don't repay, you accrue interest and that's how these banks essentially make
money. That's what I know about credit cards.
Okay.
So, where did you learn all this from?
Mostly through word of mouth, actually.
You know, my friends would be talking about credit cards and I just ask them,
you know, like, what is the need of a credit card? Why does such a thing exist? Right?
So, got it. So, have you ever tried getting one?
No, personally, I'm not really interested in a credit card.
May I know why?
So, the main thing I'm worried about is, again,
I'm sure you've heard of it, but nothing in this world is truly free, right?
So, there's always a catch behind, you know, these credit services that these banks provide.
They're essentially waiting for you to fall into the trap, right?
And I just don't want to be a part of that system.
At least for now.
Got it. Got it.
I would also say that I don't think we have enough knowledge on this subject to,
you know, confidently acquire a credit card, so, yeah.
Got it. So, do you think there's any age where you should start using credit cards?
I don't think so.
Got it. So, do you think there's any age where you should start using credit cards?
I'm not sure. In an ideal world, it would really be ideal to spend within your limits,
or spend within whatever income bracket you're in.
So, I would say there's no age where you should necessarily have to get a credit card,
but if you really had to, then, you know, best to do that as soon as possible.
Okay. So, you did mention about your friends discussing about credit cards, you and your
friends. So, what kind of discussions were these, and what were you discussing?
So, these were actually mostly on the benefits of credit cards, and you know how

cardholders. Like, you know, concessions on hotel fees, or, you know, discounts on airplane
tickets, etc. So, cash back rewards. So, yeah, it's kind of, it becomes more of a,
you know, you lose if you don't opt-in kind of system, from what my friends have told me.
So, you think you would get a card for some of these benefits, or not?
I would definitely do a few calculations before I jumped into making the decision.
Okay. Yeah.
So, do your parents use credit cards?
No, not that I'm aware of, actually.
Okay.
Okay.
My parents are actually very against taking loans of any kind, in general.
Makes sense. Okay.
Got it.
One last question. So, was there any time in the near past, like, you felt,
oh, I wish I had a credit card at that moment?
Not particularly. But there are instances, my friends, whenever we go out to eat, or we go to

And I think to myself, like, in those kind of situations, it would be quite handy having a

As I said, I'm not really eligible for a lot of credit cards.

So, if I remember, if I'm not wrong, I think you need to know that you have an income to

Got it. Yeah, they need to have proof that you can actually pay back in case you go to debt.
